hints_html: A linear approximation to a function has a concavity of 0 for all \(x\) but the function \(f(x)\) does not have a concavity of zero. Use this fact to determine if the linear approximation lies above or below the function \(f(x)\) at \(x = 7\).
hints_latex:
A linear approximation to a function has a concavity of 0 for all $x$
but the function $f(x)$ does not have a concavity of zero. Use this fact
to determine if the linear approximation lies above or below the
function $f(x)$ at $x = 7$.
hints_raw: A linear approximation to a function has a concavity of 0 for all <math>x</math> but the function <math>f(x)</math> does not have a concavity of zero. Use this fact to determine if the linear approximation lies above or below the function <math>f(x)</math> at <math>x = 7</math>.
question: 6 (c)
sols_html:
Since the second derivative \(f''(x) = \frac{-2x^{-5/3}}{9}\) is negative on \((0,\infty)\), the function \(f(x)\) is concave down there. Thus, the tangent line is an over estimate of the function and the true value must lie in the interval

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle {\color{blue} \left[\frac{23}{12} - \frac{7^{-5/3}}{9},\frac{23}{12}\right]}\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Since the second derivative <math>f''(x) = \frac{-2x^{-5/3}}{9}</math> is negative on <math>(0,\infty)</math>, the function <math>f(x)</math> is concave down there. Thus, the tangent line is an over estimate of the function and the true value must lie in the interval

:<math> \displaystyle {\color{blue} \left[\frac{23}{12} - \frac{7^{-5/3}}{9},\frac{23}{12}\right] }</math>
statement_html: Is your approximation for \(\sqrt[3]{7}\) too large or too small? Explain. Use the information together with the error bound you found in part (b) to construct the smallest interval you can guarantee contains the true value of \(\sqrt[3]{7}.\)
statement_latex:
Is your approximation for $\sqrt[3]{7}$ too large or too small? Explain.
Use the information together with the error bound you found in
{part
(b)} to construct the smallest interval you can guarantee contains the
true value of $\sqrt[3]{7}.$
statement_raw: Is your approximation for <math>\sqrt[3]{7}</math> too large or too small? Explain. Use the information together with the error bound you found in [[Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2013/Question_06_(b)|part (b)]] to construct the smallest interval you can guarantee contains the true value of <math>\sqrt[3]{7}.</math>
